results.description:
Let's meet for dinner at Himalayan Yak. I've been a couple of times and its fantastic. I would have planned for midweek but they have live music on the weekends so I thought that would make it a lot more fun. 

To make it manageable I will cap this at 12 people max, 

Re. settling the check; no offense to anyone, but I am just not a fan of separate checks as I waited tables for a long time and this was truly the bane of my existence and makes a lot of extra work for the server who is extremely busy. 

Last time we met we all put in for our portion of the bill and this worked  fairly well give or take. We did however come up a bit short but fortunately everyone was in good spirits and we all through in a few more bucks to make sure we were covered. I sincerely thank you and appreciate you being such good sports! But in the future I hope to prevent this. I'm sure you would too! : )

Absent of asking for separate checks; this is what I propose; we will all go on one tab. When we receive the check I will circulate the bill around you will initial what you had (food and drinks) and you will pay for this plus a fraction of the tax + tip (which will be equally divided by the number of people who attend).If you need to leave before the group leaves that's totally cool. Please just make sure we have the final bill and you have initialed your portion. My theory is that if everyone initials what they had than we will have an easier time noticing any discrepancies. 

Thank you very much for your cooperation!

Looking forward to more fun times : )

Melissa

**Note**

I would LOVE to do this as a group.  I am buying tickets for both admission and panic escape room.  As you review the material, this is a CONTACT horror night.  YOU WILL GET TOUCHED (Optional of course, but i want maximum experience)!!!  I'm cool with buying the tix so let's work it out.  Let's do this!!!

**Details**

Love clowns? Hate clowns? How about clowns with chainsaws?? They are ALL here this Friday The 13th for a one of a kind interactive haunted attraction contact event like no other. If you are too afraid but still want to attend, you can get one of our free protection balloons before entering, which will keep these morbid and demented clowns from devouring your soul. If you are unfamiliar with our contact events, please visit our Contact Nights page for more Info.

Our Panic Escape Rooms will also be open.  Escape Room tickets are only available in advance so purchase yours ahead of time to guarantee entry.

May 13th, 2015. Ticket booth hours are 8:30pm-10:30pm. This event may sell out so it is strongly recommended to purchase your tickets in advance. A waiver is required.

You must be at least 18 years of age to attend this event or accompanied by a parent if under the age of 18. (Your parent does not need to go through the haunt with you if you are 13 or over. They must only sign our waiver, in person, on your behalf. No, your older brother, sister, or a friend cannot sign on your behalf and the waiver is not available for download because we don’t know who is signing it. Please don’t ask). Tickets go on sale April 11th, 2016.

A gripping exercise in body horror and social paranoia, prolific Canadian director David Cronenberg's debut feature offers a startling look at modern isolationist society with a parasitic twist. When a scientist experimenting with a new form of organ transplants kills a young female resident of a fortress-like apartment complex before subsequently committing suicide, the investigation into her death leads to a frightening discovery. Originally conceived by the misguided scientist in a bid to aid organ transplant, an overzealous parasite quickly escapes into the complex in search of a host. One by one, the unsuspecting residents fall prey to the parasite, and the result is an aggressive horde of sex maniacs who will stop at nothing to satisfy their primal lust and pass the infection on through sexual contact. When the resident doctor learns the sinister truth behind the malevolent creation, only one man stands between an apartment complex overflowing with id-driven zombies and the outside world. Will he be able to stop the rapidly spreading parasite before it escapes into society, or is it only a matter of time until he, too, falls prey to its rapturous effects and gives in to the temptations of the flesh?

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eK9Wal9Dvic

results.description:
Let's dance, let's practice, and let's meet and greet @ La Fama. We are here every Friday For those who like a beginner introductory Salsa class and those who want to dance after the class. The Free beginner class, after admission is also on. Admission: $10.00 to get in. Introductory class for beginners is given at no extra charge by the instructor. Note that this will be your only expense for the entire Friday night unless you buy a beverage. But you can also bring your own beverages if you want.

Time: The event starts at 9:30pm and ends at 2:30am or until the last dancers leave. Come at any time.

Location: Times Square 151 West 46th Street, 11th Floor, New York, NY 10036 (between 7av and 6av)

Dress code: Casual/comfortable. Bring shoes that don't slip out of your feet and do not have too much grip on the floor.

Class: The Free class (after admission) at La Fama begins at 9:30pm and teaches you the basic step every Friday. If you like to take a formal Salsa dancing class that goes beyond the basics A new 12 weeks cycle will begin on February 18th. For details, join the facebook group and/or join the Class meetup group. Links below:

https://www.facebook.com/groups/453057848231239/

http://www.meetup.com/Progressive-Salsa-Classes/events/228266520/

results.description:
https://scontent-lga3-1.xx.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xtp1/v/t1.0-9/11401142_1720823001478478_3682666258495805787_n.jpg?oh=6d3a52147bbb4787f69b1b492b283ec2&oe=56D0E6E4

Every Friday Night!
Salsa Dancing in Times Square is Back!
LA FAMA (151 W 46th St, 11th Floor) is a Latin Party that specializes in playing and dancing to Salsa Music. The event takes place where the bright lights are. That's right, Times Square. We have a nice floor, great ventilation, fun willing dancers, and your total expense for a Friday Night is 12.00

Mention Salsa New York at the door and it will be $10


You do not know how to Dance Salsa? No problem. We offer a Free Salsa class at 9:30pm every Friday. So come alone or bring your friends,. Either way, you are guaranteed to learn and have a blast.
You know what else is back? The music. LA FAMA is bringing the music back to the forefront. That's Right, DJ Mustachio will be in th building playing foot stomping flavorful Salsa songs to get those hips moving and grooving.
results.name: Salsa Dancing: La Fama Mention Salsa New York for the discount !

results.description:
The Sports and Arts in Schools Foundation (SASF) Young Professional Board, the SASF Champions Council would cordially like to invite you to the 2nd Annual Kick-off to Summer Soiree. The Summer Soiree will be a night to remember under the stars on the patio of a private residence in the East Village, featuring an open bar (must be 21+ to attend), delicious food and desserts and raffles!
For tickets please go to the below site! Early bird special ends May 3rd

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sasf-summer-soiree-2016-tickets-24417067105


The Summer Soiree will immediately follow SASF’s 7th Annual Spring Arts Showcase at NYU’s Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, where hundreds of students from throughout NYC will showcase their visual and performing art talents. If you are interested in attending the SASF Spring Showcase prior to the Summer Soiree at 7 PM - 9 PM, please email [masked] to reserve your complementary seat & Champions Council VIP seat upgrade.

SASF, a non-profit 501(c)(3) organization, is New York’s largest provider of free school-based after-school programs to the NYC public school system and primarily serves children who live below the poverty line and attend academically struggling schools. Serving more than 25,000 students in over 110 schools (Grades K-12), the SASF program model combines academic enrichment with a variety of sports and arts activities.
We look forward to seeing you there!
- SASF Champions Council
results.name: 2nd Annual Kick off to Summer Soirée

21+ Dress code: upscale dressy/casual. Dressy Jeans are allowed in good taste and on your waist. (in other words No sloppy or ghetto dress. Use good judgement Thank you.)

Please read carefully: This event is being hosted by Dave Cervini's newyorksocialnetwork.com and several of their partner Meet Up groups.  The number of people you see registered on your Meet Up represent only a portion of those actually attending. If you have any questions or want to know how many are attending from all groups please contact the event host at [masked]

This is our most popular and most exciting trip, featuring dozens of fun-filled rapids combined with spectacular wilderness scenery. You’ll laugh, scream and get a little wet on the Lehigh River.  This trip is great for 1st time rafters in good physical condition.  The group will meet near Columbus Circle for the ride to the Poconos.What to expect: 10-14 members and friends who enjoy the outdoors, want to check this experience off their lists, want to get a little adrenaline rush, etc.

What to bring: bottled water, bag lunch packed in sealed plastic bag, bathing suit, towel, change of clothes.

Can I come alone? Yes, 98% of those attending will be coming on their own.

Do I need experience?  No

Return time: We will be back in NYC by 7pm

Cost: $133 includes round trip transportation, rafting fees, taxes and tips. No refund unless trip is canceled
results.name: Whitewater Rafting Dam Release: Beginners Welcome

results.description:
Break Free from Fossil Fuels in Albany is coming right up, on Saturday, May 14. 

RESERVE YOUR SEAT ON THE ROUND-TRIP, NYC-ALBANY BUS NOW! 

TO RESERVE YOUR SEAT, GO HERE


Let's have a HUGE TURN-OUT from NYC -- PLEASE SHARE THIS INFORMATION WIDELY ON AND OFF-LINE. 

What is Break Free 2016? Possibly the single most important global climate change resistance action in 2016. To find out more about the Break Free Actions going on  around the world go to <a>https://breakfree2016.org.</a>;

To learn more about Break Free Albany, sign up to take action, and receive email updates about logistics, go here: http://www.albany2016.org/ 

To deepen your understanding of why oil "bomb trains" are the primary target of Break Free Albany, view this brief video: BREAK FREE ALBANY WILL INCLUDE ACTIONS FOR THOSE WISHING TO RISK ARREST IN DIRECT ACTION, AND FOR OTHERS WISHING TO RALLY IN SUPPORT. WHATEVER YOU CHOOSE AND ARE ABLE TO DO, YOU ARE NEEDED. Break Free Albany action schedule:

Saturday, May 7: 350NYC is holding a Non-violent Direct Action Training to prepare those planning to engage in civil disobedience in Albany on May 14. The training will be from 9-12:30 pm, at NY Society for Ethical Culture, 2 W. 64th St. @ Central Park West. You need to register for the training by going to the same Eventbrite page for bus reservations above.

Wednesday, May 11-Friday, May 13: Break Free Training Camp in Albany-building action and organizing skills to take back to your community.

Friday, May 13: Break Free Flotilla, find details on Break Free Albany website link above.

Saturday, May 14: Mass Action to Stop the Bomb Trains -- non-violent civil disobedience AND support rally.

Please make Break Free Albany a priority if you can. The bigger we are, the louder our voices, the more effective we will be -- #KeepItInTheGround #BreakFree #ShutDownIndianPoint #100%RenewablesBy2030

For more info go to 350nyc.org or email us at [masked].
results.name: Break Free Albany! NYC: Reserve Your Seat on the Bus!

results.description:
THE HIKE IS ON..... It will be a moderately paced [masked]) mph. The leader will hike eastbound for about 2 hours and make a u-turn. Beginners with plenty of energy, new hikers, old timers, anyone interested in a hike filled with spring scenery with uphill/downhill hiking, accessible by public transportation, only 111 minutes from Grand Central via the Harlem Line MetroNorth train, come join us. Bring lunch, dress for the weather and comfortable footwear. Don't forget water, at least two quarts. 

The weather looks fine for today (Saturday) but showers are possible around departure time  (2:47 p.m.). I recommend bringing a small umbrella or poncho just in case.

Public Transportation: Grand Central Station, leaving at 7:50 a.m. take the Harlem Line MetroNorth train to the Appalachian Trail stop. You may also pick up the train at other MetroNorth stations. Consult a train schedule. Arrive at the Appalachian Trail train stop at 9:49 a.m. Return time will be at 2:47 pm at the MetroNorth station on the AT. Arrive back at Grand Central at around 5 p.m. Those wishing to stay longer and hike more have the option of catching the 4:47 pm train back to NYC. No shuttling needed. Everyone taking the train will be accommodated.


Driving Directions: Take I-684 from White Plains in Westchester, northbound until you reach the end, about 30 miles. Continue straight (north) on Route 22 north for another 15 miles to Pawling. Then continue on Route 22 north for another 3 miles until you see the Appalachian Trail sign and large parking areas on the left and right sides of the road. Arrive there at 9:30 a.m. The MetroNorth train station is nearby and hidden from the road. We'll walk there and greet the train.

Hike Leader: Steve Galla.  Text[masked]-2222. Inclement weather will postpone the hike. Stay in touch.

results.description:
Ready to enjoy the first warm spring days in the nature? Want to see some nice fresh green colors? Haven't you been to the Poconos yet? Then maybe you want to sign up for this two-day, 23 miles long backpacking trip about 110 miles west of New York City.

The Pinchot Trail is a 26 mile loop-type footpath in the Pinchot State Forest. Backpackers and hikers find this trail on the Pocono Plateau challenging, exciting and beautiful. It offers everything from a scenic overlook of expansive forests, a path sheltered by hemlocks next to a gurgling creek, to bog areas which contain some plants not common to Pennsylvania.


The plan is to leave NYC around 8:00 am on Saturday, drive 100 miles on I-80 West, and meet at Dunkin' Donuts in Blakeslee around 9:45-10:00 am. We regroup and drive together from there to the trail head.


The hike will be strenuous in a difficult terrain (possibly boulders on the trail and wet areas) carrying heavy backpacks. Be prepared for rain, bugs and cold weather. Everyone is responsible for themselves. You have to bring your own gear (tent, sleeping bag, stove, food, water filter, etc.), but we may share some items when possible.

Please sign up on the waiting list and as we get more drivers I'll move you to the Yes column. On Wednesday evening I'll share the carpooling and gear sharing spreadsheet with those in the Yes column. There you can sign up for a car and share your gear.

If you have questions, send me an e-mail.


More info:

http://www.dcnr.state.pa.us/forestry/recreation/hiking/stateforesttrails/pinchottrail
http://www.midatlantichikes.com/pinchottr.htm

Milos

Join us for our fun, challenging, innovative, and FREE Spring Jump Start Boot Camp. Our weight-loss boot camp combines HIIT (over 1/4-mile) Strength Training (Body Weight during Phase I), and Core. This Coot Camp is designed by a U.S. Army certified Master Fitness Trainer, and is for all fitness levels.

ONLY 20 SLOTS AVAILABLE

Our Spring Jump Start Boot Camp spans 120-yards and consists of body weight and partnered exercises. Cardio includes short sprints and longer fartlek-like runs, and Plyometrics (Don't worry, no run interval is longer than the length of the training field).

Each interval is timed, and includes recovery.

results.description:
Admission: Round Trip Ticket is $26

http://www.nysec.org/sites/default/files/styles/medium/public/images/hike_1.jpg?itok=BY3s1ouS

Join us on a hike to
Mt. Taurus in historic Cold Spring, NY.

This 5-hour hike will take us to a summit over the Hudson River. You will be rewarded with stunning views of the river and, on a clear day, Manhattan.  We will take a scenic train ride to the town of Cold Spring.  The town, set on the east bank of Hudson, has many antique stores, nice coffee shops, several restaurants, and a lovely small park.  This town is worth a day's visit even if you do not hike! 

The ride on Metro North Hudson line takes an hour and twenty minutes and offers spectacular views of the river.  We will meet at the information booth at Grand Central at 8:30am.  If you arrive after that time, find us on the train that leaves at 8:44am (Hudson Line).  The round trip ticket is $26. Please buy your own tickets.  Bring a water bottle, light lunch and/or snack for the trail, and a few dollars for a coffee stop at a local cafe.  Wear hiking or sturdy walking shoes (there are some steep parts on decent), and dress in layers for the hike.  Rain cancels

Weather permitting, come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.


Make sure you only use 3-4 of the same numbered balls. Public courts do not allow use of more than 6 balls per court.

Also please try to use the same age balls as it will help you improve your game.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.

Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the event.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
We'll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery for a run on the Old Croton Aqueduct. Afterward, whoever is interested can head to the Red Barn Bakery for breakfast. This is a good run for new runners because it is out and back - no set distance to cover but you will need to wear a watch. Feel free to turnaround at any point or walk/run at your own pace. 

Details about the Saturday run

Route: We’ll meet in front of the Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St.) in Irvington and jog VERY casually together to the Old Croton Aqueduct trail. (If you are unfamiliar with the area and would prefer to walk rather than run to the trail, click here to see the trail on a map.) From there we’ll head south toward Dobbs Ferry. There is no set distance. Everyone will walk or run at their own pace for 25 minutes, and then turn around and come back. Please wear a watch so that you know when to turn around.

Water/Bag Storage: There are very few water fountains along the route, so bring a water bottle if you need one while running. I’ll bring water and cups for after the run. There’s no bag storage, so leave belongings at home or in your car.

Location: In front of Red Barn Bakery (4 S. Astor St, Irvington, NY 10533). Free parking is available on weekends in the MetroNorth lot next door.

</a>  <a href="https://www.facebook.com/groups/1452433901730637/">Join our Facebook group to post pictures or message other members.

General advice & guidelines for our regular meetup runs:

• RSVP if you are going. If your plans change, simply change your RSVP.

• There is no bag storage, so please bring only what you plan to run with.

• All regular runs are rain or shine, unless the weather is actually dangerous.

• If you arrive late, can’t find the start location, miss us for any reason, run anyway!

Feel free to contact me either via my meetup account or at [masked] if you have any questions.

results.description:
The core of the oven is built, but we're not done yet! Learn the basics of masonry and lay bricks to build the outer facing of the oven.

Join the team to lay the beautiful red brick facing that will make this oven a twin to the Old Stone House and protect it for generations to come.  We'll also be beautifying the oven area.

This final phase of oven construction will extend over several weekends throughout the month of May. Feel free to join all day long or for just a couple of hours. No prior bricklaying experience is required!

Also, when you come help build the oven, we'll add your name to the brass dedication plaque that will be put on the finished oven. You'll go down in history as a Builder of the Oven!

We'll provide work gloves and tools.  Please wear closed-toe shoes and clothes that can get dirty.

See you there!

results.description:
Total Mileage: 8.5 miles (4 miles bushwhack)
Total Elevation Gain: about 1500'
Pace/Time: 1.5 mph / 6-7 hours, including breaks

***** READ THE ENTIRE DESCRIPTION!!

***** DO NOT SIGN UP UNLESS YOU ARE ABSOLUTELY GOING TO ATTEND

***** BE EARLY - STARTS ON TIME - RUNNING LATE YOU MISSED THE HIKE

######  Signups will be waitlisted to assure room for those who have a good record of showing up for hikes, until the day before the hike, when it will be opened for others. 

Rain cancels hike!!

West Stoppel Point (3100') & Stoppel Point (3420') are #74  & #43 respectively on the Catskills Highest 100 list.


Getting there: Take the New York State Thruway to exit 20, Saugerties. {{If you are in need of a pit stop, there is a McDonalds straight across from the exit.}}  Turn left (west) & bear right onto Rt. 32 north.  At about 6.2 miles, go left onto Rt. 32A (by Big Belly Deli).  At the traffic light, turn left onto Rt. 23A, go about 4.9 miles and turn right onto North Lake Rd. (DEC sign).  Go about 2.3 miles and turn right onto Schutt Rd..  Parking area a short ways down, on the right.  Be early -- Car shuttle leaves at 9 a.m. SHARP!! 
  
Route Description: We will be leaving some cars here and driving to the starting point, in Onteora Park.  The first 4 miles of the hike is a bushwhack.  We will pass Star Rock and ascend West Stoppel Point.  We then drop down into the col and ascend Stoppel Point, connecting with the Escarpment Trail (blue).  We'll turn left go a short distance to a great view of the Blackhead Range and the "famous" plane wreck.  We then backtrack a bit and do a very short bushwhack over the true summit to the east view of the Hudson Valley.  We then continue down the ES trail, passing super views at North Point, to the intersection of the Mary's Glen trail (red).  From the MG trail we go right onto the Rock Shelter trail (yellow), which takes us back to the Schutt Rd. parking area.

Special Gear / Requirements: Sturdy hiking boots for rocky terrain.  Warm and cool weather wicking clothing, food/water as you feel is appropriate, first aid, NYNJTC map #141 and compass.   Hiking poles can be of great assistance.

WARNING REGARDING BUSHWHACKS: "Bushwhacks" are hikes that go off of maintained trails and through pure wilderness. Be sure to wear long pants and long sleeves, to prevent getting very scratched up by tree branches, etc.  Please make sure you are very confident in your ability to navigate through the woods without trails since it is very easy to get lost in these forests, especially in the summer.  Map & Compass REQUIRED. GPS or PDF map app on cell phone/tablet, with NYNJTC Catskills map is also recommended, but it is not a substitute for a map & compass and the skills to use them effectively.  Safety glasses are a very good idea for bushwhacking.

Catskills Highest 100 List: http://www.catskillhiker.net/CHH/peak_checklist.pdf

  
Group Size: The DEC limits group sizes in the Windham-Blackhead Wilderness to 20.

---

NOTE: You are responsible for bringing appropriate gear, supplies, clothing, first aid, and lights. You should review topographic maps and trail features carefully; understanding topography of any hike is key to your knowing where you are, where you're going, and how to get back. See suggestions for GEAR on the "About" page for additional gear ideas.

You agree when you sign up for this group or any of the events that you have read and understand the below. 

If you join us for a hike (or any other event), please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on a hike signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability waiver.  Full waiver can be found on the ABOUT page.
results.how_to_find_us: Cal  --  Red Chevy Silverado truck  - Plate: HIKE*SK1
results.name: Catskills Highest 100: West Stoppel Point & Stoppel Point **Bushwhack**

results.description:
Slide, Cornell and Wittenberg (3 peaks for the price of 2)

(Slide alone 5.9 mi., 1,749 elev.  Cornell & Wittenberg alone 8.9 mi., 2,514 elev.)

IMPORTANT - As this is a car shuttle, we all need to meet at Woodland Valley to arrange transportation.  Please be prompt.  If you do not meet us here please do not expect a ride back to your car at Slide.

Groups are limited to 20 on Catskills hikes.  


Distance:  Approx. 9.5 miles, approx. 2,600 elev.

Difficulty:  Strenuous

Duration:  Approx. 7 hours

Trail Map:  NY NJ Trails Conference map #143

Weather:  Rain cancels but will make the call by midnight the night before


Parking

Take New York State Thruway to Exit 19 (Kingston).Take a right out of the NYS Thruway toll booths onto Rt 28.Go approx 35.0 miles west on Rt. 28  (approximately 1/2 to 3/4 miles past 2nd exit to Phoenicia on left side of road)Take a left onto Woodland Valley Road (look for green sign)Take a right after going over Esopus Creek (~1/2 mile from Rt 28)Go approximately 5 miles. The DEC Parking lot is on the RIGHT side of the road.  [masked],[masked]

The Hike

We aim to save 1,700' of elevation by hiking in this direction.

We will then start the hike up to Slide Mountain on the YELLOW marked trail.  We will follow that YELLOW trail for approximately 0.7 mile until we reach an intersection with the RED marked trail.  We will then make a left onto that RED marked trail and follow that for approximately 2.1 miles up to the summit of Slide Mountain (nice views, elevation 1,800 from trailhead).

We stay on the RED trail for about 2 miles till we summit Cornell. XXX 

We then continue on the RED trail and descend through the Cornell Crack till after about a mile we will summit Wittenberg.

After taking a break on Wittenberg, we will continue for about four miles on the RED trail till we hit the parking lot.  This descent will require some scrambling at the beginning, a gentle mid-section and then a steep descent to the parking lot.

Things to Do

PLEASE do this.  It will GREATLY reduce your chance of getting lost although this is heavily traveled trail.

GPS or smart phone apps

-  Google maps - pin starting point and shows peaks – DOWNLOAD AN OFFLINE MAP OF SLIDE MTN.

-  MyTracks (free) or MapMyHike (free) or some other tracking app

-  (Optional) NOT FREE – PDF Maps / Avenza – you can buy the NY-NY Trails map of the entire Catskills for $17.  This will show you were you are on the trail map.


Things to bring

GPS or Smart phone

Battery in case your phone runs out of juice


2 liters of water/liquid

Something to eat 

Dogs:  Not allowed

Guests:  No guests for this hike. All hikers must be members of WHMG.

Important: Be certain to check this webpage and your email prior to the hike for any last-minute changes or cancellations.

Important notes about WHMG hikes:

https://docs.google.com/document/d/1TKFHHQIDkgNVWs-4XmPVJM3qXp7X9B6jIrUZSWgyECU/edit

Liability Waiver: Hiking or outdoor activities have inherent risks. Your participation in our hikes or other events could be dangerous and can result in serious injury, medical emergency, even death. You agree to participate in this event completely at your own risk and to take full responsibility for your own safety and well being, including those of your guests.

results.description:
Piermont Easy
Come out and Ride!! This is a great ride to get you started. Because we are meeting at the George Washington Bridge we have a later start giving you more time to get there.
Saturday, May 14th – Piermont Easy
Where: Gorge Washington Bridge (178th Street & Ft. Washington/’A’ train to 175th)
Time: 9:15am on the pedals @ 9:30 - back by 1:30pm
Distance: 30 miles
Pace: 13mph
Terrain: Mostly flat going with some hills on the return.
Helmets are a MUST!
Weather: Current forecast indicates 74 degrees, perfect!!!
Fee: $15 Guidance & support
This beautiful journey takes us out of the city and to the quite suburbs of New Jersey and New York. The landscape is treelined and colorful. It’s a steady rolling ride at a beginners pace. that will keep your legs turning. Bring snacks to munch on during the ride. We’ll have lunch in the town of Piedmont looking out over the Hudson River North. You can also buy food in the local deli. The ride home will be a bit more challenging as at some point we need to go up!
Hope to see you there!!

results.description:
Founded in 2003, K1 Speed is the premier karting company in America. With kart racing centers nationwide, K1 Speed brings the thrill and excitement of indoor karting to a large audience. Offering highly-advanced and environmentally-friendly electric go karts as well as large indoor entertainment venues that feature authentic racing memorabilia, pit cafes, meeting rooms and pool tables, K1 Speed is a great place to visit with family and friends or to host a corporate event or party.

When it comes to go-kart racing in Poughkeepsie, there is no better option than K1 Speed! Our indoor karting center – like each and every one of our centers nationwide – is designed to be a world-class entertainment venue. If you are accustomed to go-kart tracks located on the outskirts of town in abandoned fields, you are in for a surprise! Our indoor karting center features a professionally designed race track, high-performance electric karts, and a museum collection of authentic racing memorabilia. Take everything that you think you know about karting and throw it out – we’re here to redefine your expectations!   To experience indoor karting yourself, visit K1 Speed Poughkeepsie today. Our go-kart racing is second to none, and we can assure you that you will not be disappointed! We look forward to seeing you in our center soon.*

After the races, we will have lunch at a local restaurant, and wine tasting afterward. 

Depart Date: May 14th Saturday; Please arrive 15 minutes earlier.

Depart 9:40 AM from Union Square: (Walgreen) Southeast corner of 4th Ave. & 14th St., New York, NY 10003 (Map) Subway lines (14 St-Union Sq): N, R, 4, 5, 6, L.

Depart 10:00 AM from Midtown West: (Garden City Deli) Northwest corner of West 43rd St. & 9th Ave, New York, NY 10036 (Map) Subway lines (Times Sq-42 St): A, C, E, 1, 2, 3, 7, N, Q, R, S.

Return: Expect to be back in Midtown West at 5:30 PM and Union Square at 6:00 PM

Cost: Early birds $79 if booked 7 days in advance or 1st 7 spots; Afterward Regular $89. Please only RSVP here after you have purchased the ticket.

Trip includes: Round trip transportation from NYC, Annual License & 2 K1 Speed races (14 laps each race) and wine tasting.

Buy Ticket Here: http://may2016k1speed.eventbrite.com/ or you can Chase Quickpay me the amount indicated above to [masked] to avoid transaction fee (How to Use Chase Quickpay?) When Quickpaying, please indicate your boarding location. Your spot is not confirmed until your payment is received.

Refund Policy:
* Full refund minus $10 processing fee if cancelled 7 days in advance;
* Afterward, no refund for cancellation or no show; however, you can transfer your spot to other with $10 transfer fee.

results.description:
Join us for another spectacular hike along the Palisades.

This time around we'll meet and start at the State Line Lookout are. We'll head down to the Women's Monument. 

Then continue down to the bottom of the trail and walk along the Hudson River. We'll soon hit the "GIANT STAIRS". This is about a mile long of climbing rocks as we get higher into the cliffs. Soon arriving and getting up close and personal with the bottom of the cliffs. Some really cool views of the cliffs here. 

Link to the Palisades Interstate Park Home Page

Link to the Palisades Park Map


We continue along the rocks and eventually come down back to the Hudson and to the Peanut Falls. Then a steep climb UP the cliffs and then make our way back to the parking area. Somewhere around 7 miles. But about half of those seven are tough miles. Please know your limits.  


Bring lunch and plenty of water. 


Detailed Directions:

Directions: NJ Turnpike to exit 72 on the left to rt 9/Palisades Pky. (this area is a little tricky, so follow your GPS and pay attention). Follow signs to Pky N. The state Line Lookout area is the exit in between exit 2 and exit 3 of the Palisades Interstate Parkway. It'll take you right to the parking and meeting area.  I have a blue Honda Pilot with an Outdoor Club sticker on it. I'll have on a bright yellow shirt. Look for me.

 Car pool set up from SJ  


Anybody interested in carpooling meet at 7:15 at the WaWa on Route 73 northbound, right before the turnpike entrance.

Leader - Doug Hillebrecht  M-F  9 to 5 -[masked] (work)

Cell#[masked] (till 9:30 pm)

results.description:
Total Body Bootcamp!
930am at Clove Lakes Park. Meet by the basketball courts by Clove and Victory. 

Workouts are for all fitness levels whether you’re just starting out and this is your very first workout or if you’ve been pushing hard for years. You will sweat, you will work, you... will HATE IT, but YOU’LL LOVE IT!

The workout is approximately one hour long with breaks. Each participant should bring water and a towel. Optional accessories for the workout include a yoga mat and light dumbbells if you have them. We will have some extra equipment on hand but please bring what you have.

It’s a total body workout beginning with cardio, then moving into lower body strength training, then upper body strength training then lastly ending with a core workout all while moving to the beat of some kick ass music!!

So please, come on out and get your sweat on! And spread the word!

PAGE SHARES ARE VERY MUCH APPRECIATED TO HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

results.description:
With much enthusiasm, we are pleased to invite you to the 2016 New York Baby Show, coming up the weekend of May 14-15, from 10am to 4pm each day, at Pier 92 in NYC.

The nation’s biggest show for expectant and new families, the New York Baby Show promises to be an incredible experience this year—and as a member of the NYC Dads Group community we have a wonderful invitation to extend to all of you.

For 100 NYC Dads Group families: Free New York Baby Show family pass to join us at 9:45am Opening Celebration + Free NYC Dads Group T-shirt (dads only) + Photo Ops + Britax Child Passenger Safety Workshop with Car Seat giveaways + Dads Lounge


In honor and celebration of the group’s work with dads and dads-to-be, the New York Baby Show has invited NYC Dads Group to be part of the 9:45am opening celebration and ribbon cutting on Saturday morning (5/14).  This will include all the Baby Show VIPs, local and national media, popular baby gear expert, the Baby Guy Jamie Grayson, and 100 Families (receiving free tix) from NYC Dads Group

The NYC Dads Group is one of only two parent groups in the city being honored at the opening ceremonies along with "The Moms Groups."  Bottom Line: It’s the dads and the moms this time, and we’d love to share the occasion with you.

For anyone who would like celebrate with the NYC Dads Group community at the 9:45am opening ceremony and then join us for a brief child passenger safety workshop with Britax (with chances to win free car seats), have easy access to the Baby Show at the start of the day for their entire family, and join us in the #DadsLounge, we have set aside 100 FREE Giveaway Family Tickets so you can attend the Baby Show as our guest. Please RSVP now for this event and we'll email you the free code in a few days.

For those of you who can’t make the opening at 9:45am, but would still like to attend the Baby Show on another time on Saturday or Sunday, they have set up a ticket code (DADS25) for a 25 percent discount off the Baby Show’s already affordable prices of $30 per family and $20 per individual. 

The NYC Dads Group, the flagship outpost of City Dads Group, is a community of dads that believe that fathers can be nurturing and capable caregivers. We also know that when a dad is engaged through pregnancy, birth, and the first weeks of his child's lives, he sets the foundation for a life as an active and involved parenting partner. With this in mind, we're thrilled to once again host the #DadsLounge sponsored by BabyNes at the New YORK BABY SHOW.


The DADS LOUNGE will be an upscale, warm, and inviting destination with carpeting, changing tables, couches, and glider chairs. We'll also be inviting many of our favorite dad bloggers, journalists, authors, and other parenting experts to join us in the lounge to talk about all things dad and parenting. This is the perfect opportunity to grow our group, meet new & expectant dads, and share our experiences/best practices.

CLICK HERE TO RESERVE YOU TICKETS NOW!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you're one of the first 1,500 to reserve your ticket, you will automatically be entered to win the ultimate babymoon to the Boca Resort & Beach Club, one of most luxurious resorts in the United States, and these great giveaways:

Here’s the scoop on biggest Baby Show in the country:


1. The New York Baby Show attracts thousands of expectant and new parents from New York City and the Tri-State Area by being a fun, informative, and family-friendly event to all: Women and men, couples, singles, friends, grandparents—and of course bumps, babies, and toddlers.

2. At its heart, the Show combines a big mix of top products and services for maternity, baby, and toddler, while also presenting an inspiring menu of expert speakers and beloved figures from the world of pregnancy and parenting. If you have any questions on product categories and parenting issues, you can get your questions answered at the Baby Show.

3. From the moment the Show opens its doors on Saturday, May 14, at 10am, with the help of Bobbie Thomas (the style editor of the “TODAY” show and a new mom herself), it overflows with special features and treats all weekend long—including our famous stroller test track (with all the best stroller and car seat brands to try out), big giveaways (including that wonderful Babymoon), a moms AND dads lounge, lots of trial classes and mini-concerts to share with babies and toddlers, and more!

4. The keynote speaker is the savvy, funny, and beloved BabyGuy, Jamie Grayson, who shares his tips and wisdom (and answers all of your questions) about strollers, car seats and car seat safety, crib mattresses, breast pumps, baby carriers, and much more! But keep in mind that he’s just one of an incredible group of experts speaking at the Show.

Again, for more details and information, we encourage to visit newyorkbabyshow.com.

CLICK HERE TO RESERVE YOU TICKETS NOW!

results.description:
Hi everyone,

Please be there 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt.

If this game is full click here for our calendar and see other game slots!

Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:

A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is turf so please bring turf shoes, sneakers or all terrain shoes; cleats are not allowed!

Cancellations/Refunds:

If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for any future game (please email me to issue the credit) This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List:

If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, an automated e-mail will be sent letting you know that a spot has just openned :). You can also check our calendar for other games. Click here for calendar.

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text or call Mane at[masked]-6601.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
Here is a typical agenda of Art of Speaking Toastmasters Club's meeting.


• The Sgt at Arms calls for meeting to begin

• President of the club welcomes members and guests.  Invites the Toastmaster of the day to facilitate the meeting

• Toastmaster of the Day (TMOD) introduces other duty holders.


• TMOD invites speakers who have scheduled to speak that day. Members take turns to complete their projects under the Competent Communication manual or from one of the advanced manuals. Members & Guests offer feedback to the speakers. They also fill out ballots to select best speaker.


• After the prepared speeches segment is complete, Impromptu speeches (Table Topics) segment begins. All Guests are invited to participate. The goal is to think on your feet and speak for 1 to 2 minutes. Guests & Members fill out ballots to select best Table Topics contestant.


• Short Break to enable socializing & networking.


• Meeting reconvenes. General Evaluator takes charge of the meeting. Invites Evaluators to present their feedback on the prepared speeches. Guests & Members fill out ballots to select best evaluator.


• General Evaluators returns the control of the meeting back to the President of the club.


• President gives away awards to the best speaker, best Table Topics contestant and best Evaluator.


• Meeting comes to an end approximately between 12.15 pm and 12.30 pm.

java spring mvc is bi weekly general interest open house. any questions that need answering will be answered to the best of our ability. Wed like to stick specifically to java spring framework "for right now".

If you have a question that may need a little more prep time. Ask a week ahead in discussions or comments and well answer it in the form of a tutorial the next week.

This can also be a great opportunity to also meet up with other java spring developers in the area. To network and see whats going on.

Bring a project and get to work, and draw on advice from our wonderful community. Members are strongly encouraged to bring a project to work on, or at least a laptop. 0.0

Please rsvp for the meetup if your going. Theres nothing more dull than bieng an organizer expecting people to show up only to have no one show up. Extend the courtesy please. and thanks

where meeting at the library on the 3rd floor

Also there is a seven flake rule. If your a member and you haven't shown up for one of seven concurrent groups, you will be deleted from membership. it may sound harsh but it helps to remove members who are not really interested but signed up just to sign up. And it makes room for other members who are serious about the meetup and are willing to learn from other developers in the area

results.description:
Coming up on the weekend of May 14 and 15 at Pier 92 in NYC, the New YORK BABY SHOW, presented by New York Family Magazine, is geared for new and expectant parents as well as those with toddlers from the New York Tri-State area.  


The NYC Dads Group, the flagship outpost of City Dads Group, is a community of dads that believe that fathers can be nurturing and capable caregivers. We also know that when a dad is engaged through pregnancy, birth, and the first weeks of his child's lives, he sets the foundation for a life as an active and involved parenting partner. With this in mind, we are thrilled to once again host the #DadsLounge at the New YORK BABY SHOW on May 16 and 17 at Pier 92 in New York City.

The DADS LOUNGE sponsored by BabyNes will be an upscale, warm, and inviting destination with carpeting, changing tables, couches, and glider chairs. We'll also be inviting many of our favorite dad bloggers, journalists, authors, and other parenting experts to join us in the lounge to talk about all things fatherhood and parenting. This is the perfect opportunity to grow our group, meet thousands of new & expectant dads, and share our experiences/best practices.

We hope to recruit lots of our nyc dads group members to volunteer and help us out in the dads lounge over the course of the weekend. If you're interested to volunteer and help us...please RSVP and we'll follow up to schedule a 2- 4 hour time slot.

We want to have a huge presence with many of our nyc dads group members especially our most active members.  This year, it's the mission of New York Family Magazine to "make the New York Baby Show the most dad-friendly baby show in all of the land." We'd like to help them deliver on that promise. Your role would be simple- spending time in the dads lounge sharing your unique perspective on fatherhood with dads on hand, socializing, and distributing flyers as well as walking around and enjoying the entire show.  

All volunteers will receive a code for free admission to the show, an NYC Dads Group T-shirt, and a pizza lunch.

results.description:
This class takes place on Saturday, May 14th from 10:00AM - 4:30PM with a break for lunch. 

In this class, we aim to demystify mobile app development and give you a crash course in Salesforce app building. You'll build a simple enterprise business app without writing any code. Salesforce's "low-code" platform does have front and back end programming tools, but a lot of app development is done without code. Using Salesforce's point & click platform tools, you will create a cloud database, mobile user interfaces, simple business logic, reports, and dashboards. Your sample app will run in both a web browser and on a mobile device using the free (always, forever, it's yours) Developer Edition of Salesforce and the free Salesforce1 Mobile App. 

What this class will cover:

• Overview of mobile app development

• Hands-on project building a real, working app that is yours to keep

• Resources for future self-guided learning online

Prerequisites:  

Students should be fairly familiar with using internet and mobile applications and Googling for answers to all of life’s questions. You do not need any prior Salesforce experience.

Tech Requirements:  

Please bring a laptop, not an iPad/tablet. The visual development tools only run on a modern browser (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Internet Explorer 9 or later).

Financial Need: 
A limited number of scholarships are available for those with a financial hardship. To apply, click here. Scholarship applicants will be notified a week before the class begins. Class capacity does not impact scholarship students. Check out this info sheet about getting course fees covered by your employer. 

About the teacher:

https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/eAe4G1KN7Wrvu17TapLxHDjbHZ_8pUej0H2DQdn9kpLN1mVimLsZqN06ifvtjqnaY-ibhifIaf-MlUv116u2sbnEfmaDy2PQtHAo1sFFlhNChjgRXaRAyJe9y6nSzR9urkqkJ3ha

Mary Scotton (@rockchick322004) has over 20 years of experience in enterprise software and loves the ease of development in the cloud. As one of the early members of the Platform Product Management team at Salesforce, Mary designed the core “point & click” tools that make customization and app building accessible to non-programmers. She holds several patents for those designs. These days, she spends her time educating, enabling, and having fun with the awesome Salesforce Admin and Developer community. She is focused on raising the visibility of underrepresented people in tech, and encourages hard conversations and radical inclusivity.

All attendees are expected to abide by the Girl Develop It Code of Conduct.

results.description:
Thrive in the Park is a place to meet friends, have fun and get fit.

Our *donation based workouts are designed by fitness experts and are for everyone, at any level of fitness. 

WORKOUT DETAILS:


The work out consists of body weight exercises (ex. pushup, sit ups, squats, lunges, jumps), team competitions, partner exercises, and cardio (jumping jacks, jogging, sprints, jump rope).

We do not count reps, but rather have a "do as many as you can in 1 minute" style of encouragement.

If you have any questions, please send us a message and we'll get back to you within 24 hours.

WHAT TO BRING:


A water bottle, your determination and your *donation*. All donations are invested back into Thrive in the Park

TESTIMONIALS:

Achelle - "#ThriveInThePark is the workout I look forward to all week! Not only do I get an incredible full body workout, but it's a fun and encouraging group to be apart of!"

Maria - "#ThriveInThePark is what I look forward to every week, there is nothing cooler than working out, laughing, and bonding with great people who care for their health. Rain or shine we thrive."

Andie - "#ThriveInThePark I never thought I would enjoy waking up early on a Saturday, but now I look forward to it, fun workouts with friends that keep you motivated to push yourself!"

Dani - "#ThriveInThePark I Love everything about it! Such a positive way to bring community together for some weekend activity. The guys/girls that lead the workout and stretches bring such great energy to the group, we basically laugh the whole time - until the lunges and burpees come along, no one laughs at those."

Devon - "#ThriveInThePark provides a necessary jolt of inspiration and aspiration to anyone looking to improve their life."

Ben - "#ThriveInThePark is all about community and giving back, I couldn't think about a better way to spend my Saturday mornings."

Marco - #ThriveInThePark is great because it connects mind body and soul! We learn new techniques, we motivate each other and meet interesting people from all over the world!"

HISTORY:

Thrive in the Park started in the spring of 2014. We believe in giving back to the community and in creating ripples of kindness, strength and gratitude. It is our hope that you too, will go into the world and create these ripples. 

We can't wait to see you!

LINKS:

http://www.ThriveInThePark.com 

Sponsored by: http://www.soRipe.com

results.description:
Step One:

Class and Advanced Dive Planning starts today

We will:

• Review the eLearning course and  start planning your Advanced Dives.

• Discuss Equipment use and requirements.

To complete the certification you will perform 5 Dives.

Two Days, Five Dives and

Lots of Fun

There will be at least four or five weekends schedule for these dives this season. You can also complete these dives on one of our dive trips.

So, you are Open Water Certified and want to expand your Knowledge and Skills but which course should you take next? Then SDI Advanced Adventure Diver course is for you! This course will give you an overview of up-to five specialties. Two required dives will be, the Deep Diver and Navigation Dives which are the foundation for Building a Better Diver. 

The remaining dives you can opt for include:

• Night Diving

• Advanced Buoyancy Control

• Wreck Diving

• Many more!

Typical Dive  itinerary

1. Instructor choice

2. Navigation

3. Night

4. Deep

5. Wreck

Course Fee $249.95 Pay Now

Includes:

• eLearning

• Certification dives


• C Card processing


Not included:

• Equipment


• Entry or Boat fees


Advanced Adventure offer a true introduction to the world of advanced diving. As a certified Open Water SCUBA Diver you are now prepared ready to expand your knowledge but you'd like to see what's out there first.  

Our Advanced Adventure Diver Course will give you an overview of five selected advanced specialties.

After your five dives and theory lessons, you’ll be more experienced, feel more comfortable in the water and simply enjoy diving more because you’ll better understand the underwater environment and the gear and equipment required for safe diving practices.

For most people after completing their Open Water Scuba Diver Certification, this is the natural progression on the road to furthering their diving career.


Two of the core specialties are  Deep Diving and Navigation Diving, which are the foundation of continuing diver education.

The remaining specialties include

- Wreck Diving
- Night Diving
- Advanced Buoyancy Control
- Shore Diving
- Marine Ecosystem Awareness
- Many More!

This course is intended to introduce you to Advanced Diving Specialties and not complete comprehension of the chosen specialty.One (1) dive from each of the chosen specialties may apply towards that distinct specialty certification.

Go to Our web page for more info or call the Dive Shop[masked]

Purchase your NEW gear from us and SAVE.

Why Buy Your Dive Gear From Us?

We are a company run and owned by Scuba Divers.

With over 20 years of Diving experience, we know what works and more importantly what doesn't.

We'll help you learn how to use it.

We dive and service everything we sell, so we can help you get the most out of your gear.

As a loyal customer you will get exclusive deals and discounts on everything from gear though classes. Buy with confidence as we are an Authorized Dealer for all the diving products we sell. Buy from us you never be alone.

Required Equipment: Basic open water scuba equipment (same as you used for certification dives)and a wetsuit. hood and gloves suitable for the cooler water temps at Dutch, and any other equipment that may apply to the chosen specialties.

Such as:


• Lights, for "Night Diving"

• Lift Bag and Guide Reel for "Wreck Diving".

Compass for "Navigation Dives"

Slate for Dive planning.

If you have any questions about what you need contact me at the shop or Instructor Steve.We have equipment for sale and some for rental at the dive Shop.

results.description:
Updated December 18th, 2015


WINTER (Dec-Feb)

As the city gets cold we play two times a week. We use Riverside Park with Morningside Park as a backup.

- Saturdays at 10am, Riverside Park (103rd & West End) 
- Sundays at 12pm, Riverside Park (103rd & West End)

This is one of three sites/listserves that promotes weekly games that have been going on for many many years. Stall counts are used on occasion, cleats are optional, boundaries are flexible, and all skill levels are welcome!

There are two ways to stay in touch outside of Meetup.com:

- Follow us on Twitter: http://www.twitter.com/nycultimate
- Like us on Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/nycultimate

Damien 


[masked]

RIVERSIDE DETAILS

The Riverside location is all the way West just off the water between 102nd and 108th Streets. You can only enter the park at 103rd and 108th. The best way to get there is to take the 1 local to 103rd Street. Walk West until you see an entrance that takes you down to the fields through the park. After walking down the steps from the street, you will see a path that goes left and another that goes right. Walk down the left path until you see a stone wall and stairs that go down to the fields. From South to North there will be one small soccer field surrounded by a track (red 'A' on map), another field with two softball fields (closer to 103rd/104th st) and another that is a giant soccer field (closer to 106th st). After walking down the steps, you will see the small Soccer field on your left. Start from this Southern-most field and walk North on the path to find our game. If you see no one, the meeting spot is the South side of the large soccer field. This spot is identified on the map below, a small square with little dots around it. On days when we can't find space at Riverside, we will move the game to Morningside Park (West 110th St and Manhattan Ave).

[img src="">

MORNINGSIDE DETAILS

The Morningside location is at the corner of 110th Street and Manhattan Avenue. The best way to get there is to take the C local (B on weekdays) to 110th Street. You can also take the 1 train to 110th street at Broadway and then walk East. We will play at the South end of the baseball field parallel to 110th street so that we're not in the way of the baseball/softball games. Riverside will be our backup if for some reason we need to change locations.

results.description:
PLEASE READ ALL DETAILS BEFORE YOU RSVP.

This Whitewater trip is a wet and wild 13 mile trip that runs through the breathtaking scenery of the Lehigh Gorge State Park. Hang on tight and experience the thrill of Class II and III whitewater. With 18 action packed rapids like Snaggletooth and Cookie Monster this ultimate whitewater trip is truly memorable.


You will be accompanied by a professional guide who will escort your raft from his kayak. The scenery is spectacular and you might catch a glimpse of a bald eagle soaring overhead or other wildlife grazing along the river banks.


Difficulty: Class 2 and Class 3 (Dam Release)

Length: 4 to 6 hours
Distance: 10 to 13 miles


Price: $61.00 (due during RSVP)

Rental Gear (Recommended, but not required)
Full Wetsuit: $12 
Half-suit: $6 
Farmer John: $8 
Paddling Jacket: $4 
Mitts: $3 
Boots: $5

Lunch: A pre-ordered box lunch can be ordered ($7.95) from the Red Rock Cafe.

No Squirt or Water Guns permitted on the Whitewater Section


Provided: Professional Guides, commercial grade Rafts, heated change rooms, hot rinse off showers and bathroom facilities. We also provide a paddle, life jacket, waterproof lunch container, bail bucket and free parking. All our river trips end with a free hot dog cookout for anyone who wants to participate.

If you are on a warm weather trip you should bring or wear a bathing suit, nylon shorts and shirt, a pair of old sneakers, water socks or river sandals. Footwear is required and flip flops are not allowed. We also recommend sunscreen, a towel and change of clothes for after the river trip.

What you need to bring. It is very important that you have a lunch with you for on the river. You should either bring a lunch or you can pre order a box lunch as late as the day before your rafting trip. Our Red Rock Café is on site and all of our lunches are freshly made. You will be provided with awater proof container to pack up your lunch and keep it dry until we stop along the river bank for a lunch break. Keep in mind that it is a long day so having food and drinks with you will make your day more enjoyable. You can purchase lunch at the Red Rock Café but it is important you that you arrive 20 minutes early so that you have enough time to place your order and have it ready before we leave for the River. You can find additional information about our Grille by clicking here.

Directions: The best directions you will find are the directions by clicking here. If you are using a GPS, please use the address of 1 Hunter St Nesquehoning PA 18240. If you are using Google Maps, please use the address of Paradise Rd Nesquehoning Pa 18240. Please do not use Map Quest: It will bring you to a similar address in the next town.

Our "Launch" time is 11:00 am so we need to be there early enough to change/prepare/check in. You can post below if interested in carpooling.

THERE WILL BE NO REFUNDS.

results.description:
Only $5 First Class! Come!

About Yin Yang Yoga...A typical Yoga class (as is the activity of any repetitive movement sport) is ‘Yang’ in style and focuses on active heating and muscular contraction - by starting with ‘Yin’, a more passive, nourishing, and cooling practice, this uniquely combo WILL enhance your inner and outer being, release physical, mental, and emotional tensions, chi/prana circulation, flexibility, range of movement, and focus!

Why Yin?- Lengthening and releasing effect from repetitive (walking/sitting/running/cycling) movements on sheets of connective tissue can overtime shorten and tighten it in ingrained patterns around the muscles and joints. This fascia restriction can make one more prone to having injuries, abnormal posture, and asymmetrical weakening. By targeting rotated key areas in weekly Yin Yang Yoga class, one can experience tension release and greater ease in movement******GREAT FOR RUNNERS AND CYCLISTS FOR REPETITIVE INJURY PREVENTION!

Each Yin Yang Yoga class begins with a series of held Yin/floor postures. While surrendering into the edge of each pose (for 3-5 minutes), students are guided to experience the stagnant energy and its RELEASE AROUND THE HIPS, THIGHS, AND LOWER BACK, and tune into the breath. The Yang flow designed to follow allows students to integrate the newly released energy and expand it into all the joint spaces. Guided Relaxation provided at the end will promise to be YUMMY!

______________________________________________

Testimony:

“ I started taking Jennifer's Yin/Yang Yoga for Runner's Class over the summer, and it was fantastic. I had never practiced yoga regularly before, and was pleasantly surprised at how it helped to improve my flexibility, running, and overall fitness. Jennifer is a great, hands-on teacher, and really knows how the body works. I highly recommend this class! ” Theresa

_________________________________________

By Cash or Check

ONLY $5 FOR FIRST CLASS!!

RSVP ON THIS MEETUP $15

Class Card $130/10 + 1 Class Card, or $11.82/class *****BEST DEAL!

Please dress in layers and it's okay to eat prior. Please message any questions and pass this invite to your friends. Thank you and see you under the arch!


Namaste, Jennifer, RYT-500hr

results.description:
Moderate paced, 6-mile walk along Shore Road from the Verrazano Bridge to Owl's Head Park. We will then follow the "Greenbelt" to the 8th Avenue "Chinatown" to stop for lunch. After lunch we will visit the "Park" in Sunset Park and end outside the gates of the Greenwood Cemetery (we will not be touring inside the cemetery).  The nearest subway station to the endpoint is the  25th Street stop of the R Train. 

This will be a guided tour with much commentary, between stops we will maintain a moderate pace (this is not a stroll).  There will be many places to eat, but anyone interested can join myself and others at a Dim-Sum restaurant.  We can all sit together and share a meal and then split the cost evenly.

MEET: 10:30 AM at the corner of 95th Street and Fourth Avenue (Brooklyn). Take the R train to last stop at the 95th Street Terminal.  Heavy rain cancels.

RSVP's begin 30 days prior on Thursday, April 14th at 9:00pm.  The guided tour is free with a voluntary donation of $1 or $2 to your leader to cover expenses. The historic house has a suggested donation of $3.00.  Link below of our meetup location:

http://www.angenoircafe.com/

Bushwick, now one of New York's "street art capitals" and an incubator of creative entrepreneurship, was one of the original six towns of Brooklyn, comes from the Dutch word“boswijck,” meaning “town in the woods.” Chartered by Director General of NewNetherland Peter Stuyvesant in 1661, Bushwick was settled in the nineteenth centuryby tobacco and grain farmers from France, Scandinavia, England, and Holland. In themid 1800′s a majority of the immigrants in Bushwick were German, so by 1890,Bushwick established a brewery industry, including 14 breweries operating in a 14 block area called “Brewer’s Row” and Bushwick was dubbed the beer capital of the Northeast.


The Vander Ende-Onderdonk House, adjacent to Bushwick in the Ridgewood neighborhood on the border of Queens and Brooklyn, is the oldest Dutch Colonial stone house in New York City. The house serves as a museum of the archaeology of the site which has unearthed some fascinating artifacts.

results.description:
DAY OF WELLNESS

Saturday, May 14

10:30 am - 4:30 pm


Free classes to relax your mind, body and spirit!


Classes with Chia-Ti unless otherwise noted

Come for one or multiple classes!


SCHEDULE OF CLASSES

10:30-11:30 – Pranayama & Metta Meditation

  Start the day with some peace and calm.  We will do a group practice of pranayama (breathing exercises), which can help support the immune system and relax the central nervous system.  Then we will practice Metta (loving kindness) Meditation, which is said to help open the heart and cultivate compassion. ** Please bring a cushion or yoga mat to sit on. 

11:45-1:00 –Heart-Opening Yoga Flow

  This yoga asana (poses) class will have a focus on heart-opening.  We will start with Vinyasa style sun salutations, and then focus on backbends, which help stretch the chest, combat anxiety and stress, and promotes courage.  ** Please bring a yoga mat to practice on.

1:15-3:15 – Thai Massage

  Also called "Lazy Man's Yoga," Thai bodywork rejuvenates and relaxes by stretching, pressing, and working on the energy lines of the body. Bringing calm to the mind and spirit, it also benefits one's physical health, as increased energy helps boost the nervous, circulatory, muscular, lymphatic, and digestive systems. In this class, you will learn and practice Thai massage techniques. ** Please note: You will be working in pairs but it is not necessary to come with someone. Bring a yoga mat or blanket to lie on. 


3:30-4:30 – Theta Sound Therapy

  Join Alexis Alvarez for a relaxing and healing session with theta frequency brainwave entrainment (music) and tuning fork work.  Theta waves are naturally experienced during deep sleep, and the music and tuning forks used during this session help to release energy blocks and encourages the body’s self-healing through physiological changes.  ** Please bring a yoga mat to lie on. 

Alexis Alvarez is a certified Crystal Healer, Sound & Color Therapy Practitioner, registered Metaphysical Provider and creator of Alektrik Crystals.  For more info, visit her website: www.AlektrikCrystals.com

Chia-Ti Chiu is a certified yoga instructor and Thai bodywork practitioner.  She has been offering wellness services and classes for over 14 years in NYC and around the world.  For more info, visit her website: www.onelovewellness.com

    Photo of the Thai Massage class from last year's event!

results.description:
ANTICIPATED HIKE IS ABOUT 5-6 MILES BUT MAY BE A BIT LONGER DEPENDING ON THE GROUP.


THE HIKE DOES REQUIRE ROCK SCRAMBLING AND WE WILL BE GOING OFF THE TRADITIONAL TRAIL.

PLEASE EVALUATE YOUR OWN ABILITY AND BE GUIDED ACCORDINGLY.

 Summary: This hike has amazing views and does involve rock scrambles. From parking head south along the cliff and catch the aqua blazed Long Path (LP). Shortly after reaching the LP turn left on the blue/white blazed Forest Trail and descend steep terrain on a series of switchbacks and stairs. At end of trail, turn left on the white blazed Shore Trail. The trail soon reaches a difficult, rocky area known as Giant Stairs. Be careful here as some rocks are not stable. After about a mile of rocks, you reach flat ground and pass Peanut Leap Falls (impressive after a rain, a trickle otherwise) and some ruins. Trail climbs here and reaches the LP again. For a more strenuous, scenic route, turn left on LP, cross bridge, climb steep section and return to parking. For an easier return, continue straight on LP to a distinct, unmarked trail that leaves to left (sign says To Park Office). Take this. At end turn left onto old Rt 9W (closed to vehicles) and return to parking lot.

Depending on the size of the group we may split up into two groups to allow the group hike at their own pace.

GPS COORDINATES MAY BE OFF A BIT SO FOLLOW DRIVING DIRECTIONS:

Take the Palisades Interstate Park north from the George Washington Bridge. Continue for 1.7 miles beyond Exit 2, and turn right at a sign for the State Line Lookout. Follow the access road for about half a mile until it ends at a large parking lot near the lookout. (If you are coming from the north on the Parkway, bear left just beyond Exit 3 and follow the signs for the lookout)

MINIMUM RECOMMENDED GEAR:

· Backpack (keep in mind we will be climbing and crawling over rocks so your pack should not be too heavy or too big)

· Hiking Poles (They will not be able to be used while scrambling so you need to make sure there is a way to secure them so your hands are free)

· Hiking shoes with good traction. The rocks can be slippery especially if it rains a day or two before the hike.

· Water at least 2-3 liters

· Snack and lunch

THIS IS A MEMBER ONLY HIKE. IF YOU WOULD LIKE TO HIKE WITH A FRIEND WHO IS NOT A MEMBER PLEASE HAVE THEM JOIN THE GROUP. There is a $2 suggested donation for this event to cover the cost of the meetup site.

BAD WEATHER WILL CANCEL HIKE. PLEASE CHECK YOUR EMAIL FOR UPDATES 

You agree when you confirm your attendance you are hiking AT YOUR OWN RISK and you have read and understand the below. 

If you join us for an event please understand that you are responsible for your own preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation that may happen at a planned event. You are responsible to research the event, know the area, and use the proper gear.

results.description:
We're going to see "Munch and Expressionism," an exhibition that examines Norwegian artist Edvard Munch and his influence on his German and Austrian contemporaries, as well as their influence upon him.


The exhibition contains 35 paintings and 50 works on paper. Artists include Munch, Max Beckmann, Erich Heckel, Ernst Ludwig Kirchner, Gabriele Münter,  Emile Nolde, Richard Gerstl, Oskar Kokoschka, and Egon Schiele. The show compares these artists’ approaches to key themes such as adolescence, urban anxiety, and self-portraiture, and to innovative developments in printmaking during this time.


Here's a link to the exhibit:  

http://www.neuegalerie.org/content/munch-and-expressionism-0

And here's a review:

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/02/19/arts/design/review-the-darkness-and-light-of-edvard-munchs-work.html?_r=0

The museum opens at 11.  We'll meet in line (outside the museum) at 10:45.  Please be prompt.  I want our group to be among the first people to enter, because the museum gets very crowded very quickly.  Admission is $20.


If something comes up and you can't attend, please change your RSVP status as soon as possible.  Given the small size of this meetup group, no-show's would be a big loss.

results.description:
Nir Levanon will lead a discussion of one of the most fascinating aspects of quantum mechanics - Delayed Choice Quantum Eraser where the outcome of an experiment depends on what the experimenter knows rather than on what the experimenter does.

Time permitting, I will present a few cosmic puzzles that hopefully will gain some clarification during the session (for full disclosure: I don't know the answers). In particular: is it at all possible to determine the age of a black hole based on its Hawking radiation? can thought experiments disprove black hole complementarity  and the holographic principle?

If still more time is available: any issues/topics frpm any of the participants.

Cheers,

Moshe Rozenblit, PhD
results.name: Delayed Choice Quantum Eraser. cosmic puzzles and other frills

results.description:
Hi Everyone,

I am pleased to let you know that Sarah Owen of BK17 Bakery will be offering a hands-on baking class on Saturday, May 14.  Last fall, NYC Ferments, hosted Sarah for a book signing, and I know many of you were eager to take a class with her.  Details on the Haven's Kitchen and Just Food sponsored event are below.  

If you are interested, act quickly, as the class is limited to 12 people!  You must register through the Haven's Kitchen.  

Best,

Angela Davis

NYC Ferments Co-organizer

DESCRIPTION
Sarah Owens, the founder and baker of BK17 Bakery and the author of the James Beard Foundation-nominated book, Sourdough: Rustic Recipes for Fermented Breads, Sweets, Savories, and More, will be teaching a hands-on class about the basics of the mysterious medium of sourdough, a natural leavening. Students will learn the process from start to finish: from maintaining a starter, to mixing, shaping, scoring, and baking in the home kitchen. Students will leave with dough to bake at home, some starter, and a few basic recipes. Snacks and wine will be provided.

All proceeds of this class will be donated to Just Food.

Registration fee: $115.00

Click here to register.  You must reserve your spot in the class through Haven's Kitchen. RSVPs on Meetup will NOT reserve your spot.  

All class sales are final. Students must cancel at least 72 hours before the scheduled class to receive a Haven’s Kitchen credit of the full purchase value. 

MEET THE CHEF


Sarah Owens is a professional horticulturist, former steward of the Cranford Rose Collection at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden, and the founder of BK17 Bakery, an artisan microbakery specializing in sourdough that serves NYC. Sarah's customers receive freshly baked goods delivered through a subscription based on seasonally available ingredients and stone-ground heritage grains. She has been featured in Edible Brooklyn, on Gardenista, and also 66 Square Feet. She has also appeared on the Martha Stewart Show. Her botanically-inspired book Sourdough: Recipes for Rustic Fermented Breads, Sweets, Savories, and More is nominated for a 2016 James Beard Award.
results.name: BAKING BASICS: SOURDOUGH 101, A Benefit Class for Just Food
