results.description:
IMPORTANT: Due to limited space and security, you MUST RSVP on link here. If you just RSVP on meetup without a ticket, you will NOT be able to get in.

Cancellations: This event is free due to Bloomberg's generous support. Email [masked] as soon as you know you cannot use your ticket. We'll release your seat for one of your fellow practitioners and generate good IxD karma for all involved! Please notify any cancellations by Thursday, May 12th.

Join the Interaction16 Redux, a one-day conference in New York City featuring a selection of the best presentations from the IxDA international conference, presented by IxDA New York and Bloomberg, 

Every year, the interaction design community gathers in one place to stretch our minds, sharpen our skills and inspire each other. Every year numerous people are unable to attend and partake in this incredible opportunity – so we’re bringing the conference to you!

SCHEDULE
11:00 - 11:30 Check-in/Breakfast

11:30 - 11:45 Opening remarks

11:45 - 12:45 Opening Keynote: Learning From Live Systems by Josh Seiden

12:45 - 01:00 Coffee Break

01:00 - 01:30 Invisible Cities by Pablo Honey

01:30 - 02:00 Box Lunch

02:00 - 02:30 Shallow Interaction Patterns for Deeper Human Experiences by Kieran Evans and Jes Koepfler

02:30 - 03:30 Closing Keynote: Magical UX and the Internet of Things by Josh Clark

03:30 - 03:45 Closing remarks

03:45 - 05:00 Refreshments and Networking

ABOUT OUR SPONSOR BLOOMBERG

How do we describe the design challenges posed by one of the world’s most important financial software ecosystems? Complex and vast, for a start. And that’s what Bloomberg’s Financial Products UX team lives for. Solving big issues and defining the user experience for a product where billions of dollars are at stake. We operate in nimble, high impact teams within a company that values our work deeply. This is a place for passion and dedication, ideas and humility, where seriousness of purpose and a sense of humor are the fuel we run on.

Working at Bloomberg
We’re looking for smart thinkers in our New York City headquarters! For passionate, talented, ready-for-any-challenge UX professionals across a range of experience levels, Bloomberg is the place to be. Currently we are hiring contractors for data visualization, interaction design, icon visual design, and technical writing. Visit http://www.bloomberg.com/ux/and click on "Careers" for more information. Or, contact Matt Jabinsky and Christine Hauer in UX Recruitment.

ABOUT IxDA
With over 50,000 members and more than 150 local groups around the world, the IxDA network actively focuses on interaction design issues for the practitioner no matter his or her level of experience. IxDA is a novel kind of “un-organization” and relies on its passionate members to help serve the needs of the international Interaction Design community.

The IxDA New York City local group is a vibrant community of people interested in interaction design who meet monthly at face-to-face events. Programming is created by a volunteer group of local leaders and realized through the generosity of speakers, sponsors, and host partners.

To learn more about IxDA, please visit http://www.ixda.org

ABOUT THE PRESENTATIONS

Magical UX and the Internet of Things
Josh Clark  (Josh's Biography)

"What if this thing was magic?" Designing for the internet of things means blessing everyday objects, places, even people with extraordinary abilities—requiring designers, too, to break with the ordinary. Designing for this new medium is less a challenge of technology than imagination. Sharing a rich set of examples, designer and author Josh Clark explores the new experiences that are possible when ANYTHING can be an interface. The digital manipulation of physical objects (and vice versa) effectively turns all of us into wizards. Sling content between devices, bring objects to life from a distance, weave "spells" by combining speech and gesture. But magic doesn't have to be otherworldly; the UX of connected devices should build on the natural physical interactions we have everyday with the world around us. The new UX must bend technology to the way we live our lives, not the reverse.


Shallow Interaction Patterns for Deeper Human Experiences
Kieran Evans and Jes Koepfler (Kieran's Biography) (Jes's Biography)

Shallow interaction design is a new way of thinking about human-computer interaction. We define shallow interaction design as the patterns and features of an experience that promote surface-level interactions with technology devices to minimize distraction. In this session, we will discuss how we applied shallow interaction design in Extreme Event, a social game that teaches players about disaster resilience. We’ll describe and demonstrate 6 shallow patterns that we used in the creation of this game to ensure that digital interactions played only a supporting role to the human-to-human interaction. We’ll conclude with a group discussion about other domains, such as healthcare and wearables, where shallow interactions will play a critical role in the future.


Invisible Cities
Pablo Honey (Biography)

Cities have always been the driving forces behind the economic and cultural development of a region, a country or a continent. But one thing does distinguish this day and age: the speed of that development. And the most radical booster of that speed is the upshot of the internet, an innovation that is only 40 years old.

Big cities will be developing into megacities, and today’s megacities will turn into super-megacities. Specially in these ever-changing metropolis we are seeing the interplay of different trends tapping into mobility, robotics or energy.

But every institution is following an isolated agenda, rather than a collective effort to tackle the challenges of those future cities.

This talk is meant to give an holistic view to how the cities are changing and how as Experience Designers we can enhance the physical and digital spaces that we live in.


Learning from Live Systems (Opening Keynote)
Josh Seiden (Biography)

At Interaction '11 in Boulder Colorado Dick Buchanan told us that an interaction is "how people relate to other people through the mediating influence of products."

Earlier, at Interaction '09 in Vancouver, Robert Fabricant told us, that "interaction design is not about computing technology." Instead, he argued that "Behavior is our medium."

These statements have become uncontroversial in the world of interaction design, and yet when we talk about design methods, we still talk about methods for designing products and for human-computer interfaces. We have a body of methods to design products (the "mediating influences") but very few tools and approaches available to work with the larger systems of interaction.

Recently though, we've seen teams having success with methods that blend Service Design, Lean Startup, and Lean UX methods into what I call "Learning From Live Systems" approach. By launching services early and powering them with a mix of software and human "concierge" services, teams are able to develop and test systems even as they are under construction.
results.name: The Interaction16 Redux

results.description:
You are invited to join Women of Culture for an afternoon of history, herstory, art and architecture. This is not a tour for tourists — though 'tourists for a day' are more than welcome! Rather, this is a unique opportunity to experience a very special part of the city, one that we often take for granted, in a whole new way.

We will literally be transported back to a time of opulence, indulgence and female empowerment in order to walk in the footsteps of some of America's first independent women and discover the secret herstories of this magical neighborhood!

Professional artist and tour guide, Mark Venaglia, will lead us on a journey full of architectural gems, scandals and love triangles, and will 'introduce' us to some of the first female entrepreneurs and original Women of Culture.

We will stand in the exact same places where America's first independent women passionately networked, fired up the Suffrage Movement, influenced culture and forever changed the interface between men and women!

Mark has custom-designed this tour exclusively for Women of Culture and will present all this (and much more) from the passionate point of view of an artist, full of personal and unique touches. There are hundreds of tour guides in the city, but no other that possesses Mark's charisma, dedication, knowledge and enthusiasm, which is evident in the time he has taken to carefully plan and research every detail of this event.

First, we will meet and mingle at Tarallucci e Vino before heading out on our 2 hour walk, which will be completely at our pace, with ample time for rest stops and coffee breaks as needed.

I can't emphasize enough that this is NOT a pre-packaged tour and will be even further tailored on the spot to our particular interests and energy levels. Attendees will also receive a commemorative map of our route, hand-illustrated by Mark — and of course the opportunity to 'meet' some exceedingly cultured women of both the past and present!

Whether you have lived in New York for days or decades, after this tour, you will never see the Flatiron District in the same way again! Here are just a few of the reviews for our tour guide, to give you a taste of the amazing-ness that is in store for us!

"If you're looking for a traditional tour full of lectures and stodgy viewpoints, this tour is definitely not for you."
— Anemone W. (New York, NY)

"The hours flew by. His enthusiasm swept 30 sophisticated cynics upon a magic carpet ride!"
— Beatrice I. (Malibu, CA)

"Mark's art knowledge is impressive without a hint of pretension; his energy infectious."
— Matt M. (Wilmington, DE)

"Not only is Mark Venaglia one of the most knowledgeable art historians I know, he is also by far the most dynamic communicator. He makes art of any period exciting and relevant; with boundless energy — and he is FUN."
– Annie C. (The J. Paul Getty Museum - Special Events)

I hope you will join me for this very unique and special opportunity.


Get your tickets here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/gibson-girls-department-stores-votes-for-women-a-gilded-age-walking-tour-of-the-flatiron-district-tickets-24725178675

DESCRIPTION:
There are 24 named waterfalls in Ricketts Glen State Park in the U.S. state of Pennsylvania along Kitchen Creek as it flows in three steep, narrow valleys, or glens. They range in height from 9 feet (2.7 m) to the 94-foot (29 m) Ganoga Falls. Ricketts Glen State Park is named for R. Bruce Ricketts, a colonel in the American Civil War who owned over 80,000 acres (32,000 ha) in the area in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, but spared the old-growth forests in the glens from clearcutting. The park, which opened in 1944, is administered by the Bureau of State Parks of the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources (DCNR). Nearly all of the waterfalls are visible from the Falls Trail, which Ricketts had built from 1889 to 1893 and which the state park rebuilt in the 1940s and late 1990s. The Falls Trail has been called "the most magnificent hike in the state" and one of "the top hikes in the East".

NOTE: Tentative Start Dates! We will officially begin practice when the boats are launched in Mid-April. 

Arowana's Dragon Boat season runs through mid-September.

The new members will meet up on the docks promptly approximately 30 minutes before the start time. We will require waivers to be filled out and then start with stretches followed by basic dragon boat paddling technique with you on land. Afterwards, we will take the boat out and paddle. No previous skill required. We will provides life vests and paddles. We recommend bringing a bottle of water, sun screen and wear clothing that you will be OK getting wet, swimwear being best. Shades, gloves and hat are worn by most of our paddlers as well but are not required. Practice lasts roughly 2 hours.

IMPORTANT NOTE: Our practices are on a first-come-first-serve basis. We may or may not be able to accommodate everyone on any given weekend, and there may be a waiting list on the event. Please update your responses if your plans change so that we may make space for those on the wait list.

PLEASE NOTE EARLY SEASON PADDLING WILL BE COLD, BRING A WATERPROOF JACKET!

Sometimes we grab lunch afterward in Flushing, you are welcome to join us.

This series of Meetups is catered to introduction to dragon boat. Our veteran members will be paddling alongside you as well. If you like'd to be added to our team mailing list, please ask Lin or Selene for additional details.

Arowana will be participating in The New York Hong Kong Dragon Boat Festival in Corona Park this August and possibly other races during the course of the year.

results.description:
We are so excited that EARTH - Environmentalist Animal Rights Team of Hoboken will be participating in Hoboken's 5th Annual Green Fair! It is Saturday, May 14th with a rain date of Saturday, May 21st. 


The purpose of the Green Fair is "to introduce sustainable lifestyle choices to the community, raise awareness regarding environmental issues, and demonstrate how consumers can reduce their impact on the earth by selecting sustainable, eco-friendly products and services." What is the best way to reduce our impact on the earth? Go vegan of course! We will have a table and will be providing free vegan food samples and literature with an environmental focus. We will also be showing short video clips such as the one below:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g1z1taw6yNw

So how can you help? While the organizers (Kelsey, Owen, Michal, and Paloma) will be at the table giving out samples and showing clips, you could help us by leafleting around the the park (and guiding people to our table), writing vegan chalk messages, or possibly even helping us behind the table as we may need help preparing the samples, setting up, cleaning up afterwards, etc. 

You may also just want to enjoy the festivities! There will be live music and food vendors (hopefully some veggie food!). You can find the link to the event here.


We have been getting ready!

Also, the week following the Green Fair we will be screening the documentary, Cowspiracy, at the Hoboken Library! Be sure to sign up for that event as well, here:

http://www.meetup.com/Hoboken-JC-Vegan-Activist-Meetup/events/230821700/

We are going to invite those we interact with at the Green Fair to attend. We will also have an email sign up sheet so that we can keep in touch with people in the community who want to learn more about eating sustainably. Please try to join us for that event as well! 

We hope to see you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the booth with the EARTH banner!

results.description:
“You are a function of what the whole universe is doing
in the same way that a wave is a function of what the whole ocean is doing.” 

– Alan Watts

The is the start a new series I'm calling Buddhism and the Self. We will look more closely at the Buddhist teachings regarding our common belief that we are an individual, separate "self" versus a deeper realization and understanding of our true nature being an interdependent and interconnected part of the whole universe.


We know from the Four Noble Truths that the goal of meditative practice is to end the suffering that exists in life for each of us.  From the teachings we are invited to investigate and awaken to who we really are at the deepest levels. Once we notice that our belief in an independent and separate self makes anything that isn't "us" a possible threat, we can understand why we constantly struggle with anger, craving, jealousy, pride and ignorance as we navigate the world with other beings and experiences. 

From those many struggles we develop our "rules of engagement" that strongly influence all of our life choices from what we wear, with whom we associate, to what we do for work. Of course, there is nothing wrong with having inner confidence about our life, but the teachings suggest that we are identifying with an incomplete or even wrong version of ourselves.

Over the next few weeks we'll look at what the Buddha explained as the five aggregates, or groups, or bundles of things that work together to form the sense of self. These teachings are fundamental in Buddhism and provide a window into how our relationship with the "self" is constructed.

I hope you'll share your Saturday morning with us.

Class Structure:  

Each class begins with a very brief guided meditation of gathering and quieting followed by a topical teaching and an expanded guided mindfulness meditation. There is time for discussion and Q&A.  Please note that while there is benefit in participating in regular sittings and practice, you do not have to attend every class to find value. 

Fee by donation: Suggested starting donation is $10 and your generosity is greatly appreciated.  No one is ever turned away for lack of funds.  The donation box is on the sign-in table.
results.name: Buddhism and the Self - Introduction

results.description:
Join Outdoor Afro for an Uptown urban walk at Highbridge Park(Washington Heights, NYC) on Saturday, May 14th from 11a-1p!  Our walk will take us through the park and across the Highbridge. 

Fun fact - the Highbridge, built in 1864, is NYC’s oldest standing bridge, spanning from Manhattan to the Bronx.  This beautiful bridge was just reopened to pedestrians in 2015 (after being closed for 40 years), so if you’ve been meaning to get there to check out the amazing views, now is your chance!  

We will walk about 2 miles, so comfortable shoes are a must! We will walk at a moderate pace so all skill levels (including children) are welcome.  After the walk, there will be an optional opportunity to grab a quick bite at a local café with your fellow Outdoor Afros.

This event is easily accessible via public transportation – the closest subway station is 168th St (A/C/1 train). Please note that we will meet at the park entrance at the corner of W. 165th St and Edgecombe Ave.  (This entrance is ramp accessible for wheelchairs or strollers.)  Remember to bring at least 24oz of water!  

Look forward to seeing you guys Uptown!

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 30-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use turf shoes or sneakers. 6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and throw-ins and 6'x15' big goals. Rotate goalies

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:The field is located on the corner of West 134th street and Amsterdam Ave. Click on this Google link for location: Click here.

Directions: By train: 1 train to 137th St. City College Station

Late arrivals:

If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:

Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

results.description:
I've been wanting to do this event ever since I saw Margret do it for CB2 and now that I live in Queens, what better time than now!! Long Island City (LIC) is quickly becoming a beer and food haven and I want to explore all it's got to offer.  The plan is to visit 3 of the LIC breweries and the beer/food outdoor market, LIC Flea & Food.  These breweries' tasting rooms are small so I have to cap this event.  The rough plan for the day is as follows:

Noonish: LIC Flea & Food- this is an outdoor market with food, beer, shops, and even some games to play.  Ideally, get something to eat here before the beer tastings begins.  We'll spend some time here gathering the troops, eating, and doing whatever else. 

1pm: Rockaway Brewery-  this brewery is across the street from LIC Flea & Food.  These beers you can easily find all around NYC as they are the biggest of the LIC breweries.  The tasting room is small and hot but dammit, we aren't at a spa, we are here to taste some beer!

2:30pm: Big Alice Brewing Company- about a 10 min walk north long the river will get us to the most experimental brewery in LIC.  They are making some really weird beers so the tasting flight is the way to go here.  

4pm: LIC Beer Project- a 15 min walk will get us to the brewery I'm most excited about.  They specialize in wild yeast so be prepared for a tap menu full of sours, farmhouse ales, and saisons.  This tasting room is a little bigger than the last ones but it will likely still be tight.  

It will be likely be around dinner time when we are done with the crawl so people can split up and do what they like: hit some local spot for food, hit up another bar, go home and sleep, whatever.  We'll see where the day takes us.  These times are super rough, I go with the flow and how everyone is feeling.  I will post when we move in case anyone gets lost.

Cash is going to make your life much easier.  I know a couple of these spots have a credit card minimum and a tasting flight doesn't make the minimum. 

Subways: Arriving to the event is easiest via the Vernon Blvd 7 stop.  The Court Sq. E M isn't too far away either.  Leaving the crawl will put you closest to the Queensbridge F, Queensboro Plaza 7 N Q, and Queens Plaza E M R stops.
results.name: LIC Brewery Crawl

results.description:
IMPORTANT MEETING INFORMATION:

(1) For submissions, please email them to me (Evan) at eberkow (at) gmail (dot) com. Thanks!

(2) As a disclaimer to anyone who might be allergic, I have one dog and two cats who will be bumbling around my apartment during the meetup. The dog is especially sweet and may beg for head-petting from some or (more likely) all of you.


This group is for developing book-length manuscripts or working on standalone pieces (Short Stories, Flash Fiction, Novels, Novellas, Poems, Creative Non-Fiction/Memoir, Etc.)

This is a new critique group with a new format. We will focus on short stories, flash fiction, novels/novellas, poetry, creative non-fiction/memoir, with some participants having the end goal of putting together book-length manuscripts. This is a speculative fiction group so the work should be in the magical realist, surrealist, horror, sci-fi, fantasy, etc. genres. American Gothic and poetic memoir would fall into these categories. This group is broad and is a good space to submit works that may not fall clearly into a set format.

For the first group, please submit a 3-5-page sample and a mission statement/end goal. I am putting together a shared Google drive to distribute the work to everyone who will be attending the meeting.

We will follow stories, chapters from novels, poems, pieces/vignettes, flash works that center around a shared world or set of characters so that we can support each other's progress throughout the process of creating either the finished manuscript or working on separate pieces. If you are already in a novel group, you are welcome to bring another novel or a different work to this meeting, but please don't submit a novel that is already being critiqued by a novel group.

The format will be slightly different than the critique groups that utilize the Clarion method. Everyone will have the chance to participate and give critiques. When submitting a piece for the first time, the author will let us know what their vision is for the finished manuscript: approximate length, overarching themes, goals during the writing process, what their driving force is for writing this manuscript. When submitting the work for critique, the author will write three questions/areas that they would like readers to focus on or special challenges they have had in writing. During the meeting itself, the critique process will follow the same rules of respect and constructive criticism as the other meetings. The only difference will be that everyone will talk in their own time: we will not go around the circle in the set fashion of the CM but will listen to critiques coming from whoever would like to speak. The author will be silent for the duration of the critique and then have the chance to ask the group any questions based on the comments they heard.

Page count per submission and per meeting will be the same as for the other critique groups:

7,500-word limit/submission

28,000-word limit/meeting
results.name: Blurring the Lines: New Multi-Format Critique Group

results.description:
WHAT IS RETURN TO THE RIVER?

Return to the River is a weekend-long celebration that brings together the students and families in our youth development programs, the members in our adult sailing club, and the general public to showcase the great things happening at HRCS. On Saturday at our Chelsea location students will bless, launch, and sail the wooden boats they have been building all winter! Volunteers and staff will offer short sailing lessons to the general public free of charge. There will be food, music, and nautical activities on the Pier, and maritime themed workshops in our classroom.  On Sunday at our Uptown location there will be free sails for the public.

WHAT WILL IT BE LIKE WHEN I SHOW UP?

There is a lot going on all day, including our Youth Programs launching and sailing their wooden boats.  For adults, you can watch along and there's also adult sailing.

CAN I GO SAILING?

Yes, in fact, there's free sailing, but the only way to sign up is through the Return to the River page.

results.description:
I am a therapist, divorce mediator, and adjunct professor at NYU with a specialization in eating disorders. I am interested in helping to facilitate a monthly meet-up group to discuss experiences, treatment options, and helpful ideas in dealing with eating disorders of all types. I have years of experience treating bulimia, binge eating, anorexia, and issues of body image, with excellent results.


In addition to seeing patients individually for eating disorders (among other issues), I'm currently forming an ongoing, weekly therapy group for persons with eating disorders who are looking for something more ongoing and intensive. I work on a sliding fee scale, so I will do what I can to make it work for you. My approach is a combination of psychodynamic, cognitive-behavioral, and Buddhist principles, with a healthy dose of compassion and understanding!

Our meetups are held in Union Square, near 12th Street and University Place.

Please give me a call or email me if you think you might be interested in attending the meet-ups or in learning more about individual or group therapy. Space is somewhat limited, so if you are interested, it's best to call or email me right away.


Thank you!


Judie Stein, Ph.D., L.M.S.W.
Director
Stein Mediation & Family Center


(212)[masked]
[masked]

www.steinmediation.com

results.description:
Each spring Randall's Island Park Alliance’s annual Cherry Blossom Festival ushers in the warmer months, and gives visitors the opportunity to appreciate the park’s spring beauty. 

Set along the backdrop of the Hell Gate Bridge and the Urban Farm, the festival welcomes the park’s cherry blossoms with live music, performances, games, exhibitions, face painting and more, inspired by Japanese culture. 

This year, in conjunction with the Cherry Blossom Festival, Randall's Island Park Alliance will host its annual FLOW Grand Opening, which features five new site-specific installations by artists, in partnership with the Bronx Museum’s Artist in the Marketplace program (AIM).


This event will provide a variety of photographic opportunities for everyone - landscape, street, abstract, etc. The possibilities are limitless.

This is event is being held by the NYC Parks Dept. and there will be a crowd. Try to be on time. We will start on time.


Disclaimer: Participation in these events requires that you assume all risks associated with these activities, and that the Organizers, Co-Organizers and Event Hosts are in no way liable for any loss or injury as a result of your participation. In other words, you are attending these events at your own risk!!

P.S. Remember to format your cards, charge your batteries and come with your enthusiasm to make new friends!
results.name: Experience the Cherry Blossom Festival on Randall's Island Park

results.description:
The NYC Texas Exes are at it again.

It's time for their annual Texas Chili Cook-off, and tickets are on sale now! Your all-inclusive ticket includes admission, all-you-can-eat chili (while it lasts) all-you-can-drink Shiner beer, live music, and more.

BONUS: Use promo code TEXPATS2016 for a special Texpats discount!

Individual early-bird tickets are $50 and team tickets have been reduced to $75.

THIS EVENT WILL SELL OUT – buy your tickets early to guarantee admission. Remember to use the TEXPATS2016 promo code.

All proceeds benefit the New York Texas Exes Scholarship Fund. So whether you are a Texan or just like great chili and great fun, come out and enjoy some chili, Shiner, live music, and sunshine - all for a good cause!

NOTE: This is an unhosted event. Please purchase your own tickets for the Texas Chili Cook-off using the Ticketfly link.

If y'all want to meet up early for drinks or want to coordinate post-event activities, please use the comments section (below) on this event page.

https://www.ticketfly.com/purchase/event/1119753

Whether you’re new to fitness or have been working out for years, NYC In Your 20s is offering New Yorkers of all shapes, sizes and abilities FREE workout motivation every Saturday at 12:30 PM for six weeks, starting April 16, 2016.

NYC In Your 20s is helping New Yorkers get beach body ready by hosting their first annual fitness classes.  Over the course of six weeks, certified fitness trainer and nutritionist Oscar Flores and fitness instructor Bakari Taylor guide students through a warm-up before blasting through a series of fun, high-low impact choreographed workouts.  Suitable for people of all levels and free for everyone.  Sense of humor and flexible workout clothing required!

results.description:
In this IFA online lecture Horst Bredekamp, Professor of Art History, Humboldt-University of Berlin, follows a chain of examples from antiquity to the twentieth century's Niki de Saint Phalle's happenings in order to question the traditional concept of the relationship between the work of art and the beholder. Conceptualizing the theory of picture-act, which tries to develop alternatives to traditional concepts of representation, illustration, and mimesis. Dramatizing this problem, Leonardo da Vinci created the formula that pictures “imprison” the audience.

The lecture can be viewed at the following link:

https://video.ias.edu/audience-as-prisoner

If you can't review the material discussed feel free to audit. A voluntary donation of $3.00 will be requested at the meetup to defray the cost of maintaining this website.
results.how_to_find_us: 2 blocks south of Union Square in the Village.
results.name: The Audience as Prisoner: Activity of the Object

results.description:
Spring is upon us and I have something awesome for you to do with all those books you loved, but have been hoarding on your shelves, and in your closets & garages... swap those old stories for new adventures!


How it works: Everyone brings up to 10 books they're ready to part with; we mingle, pick out new-to-us books to take home, and the remainders get donated to a women's shelter or senior center (TBA)... everyone wins!


You will receive (1) ticket for each of your accepted books. Each ticket may be redeemed for (1) new-to-you book.  


Guidelines:


~Books for Young Adults (YA) and older are welcome. DO bring any type of fiction & literature. DO bring nonfiction titles (i.e. memoirs, biographies, cookbooks, self-help... books you would recommend to people you know). 

DO NOT bring children's, teen, academic/study aids, reference books, or magazines. I cannot list every genre here, but you get the idea; please use your best judgement.

~Books must be in good condition. Books that have missing or teared, stained, molded, covers or pages and/or have obscured words will not be accepted. Denied books will be returned to you; we cannot dispose of or donate them for you.

~This is a free event; however, you will be asked to make a suggested donation (of $1, $5, $10, etc.) when your books are collected (cash only). All proceeds will go to the women's shelter or senior center (TBA). Bringing at least one book is required to participate in the swap. 

Hope to see you all there!

xo,

Noëlle
results.how_to_find_us: 3rd Floor, Room A
results.name: BOOK SWAP: "Spring Cleaning for Summer Reading (& Charity)"

results.description:
About the festival:
With the Ninth Avenue Food Festival, Hell’s Kitchen comes alive like no other neighborhood in New York. It’s a truly international food festival with delicious treats you won’t find at any other fair.

From 42nd Street to 57th Street, Ninth Avenue closes to cars and the festival takes over. More than a million people visit the food festival each year. It’s unique and amazing, celebrating the joys of ethnicity through food, entertainment and every kind of street fair stall.

The food is the big draw, but the festival is a fabulous expression of the Hell’s Kitchen neighborhood – teeming with ethnic food shops and fine restaurants and offering an eclectic global smorgasbord of national and regional foods. Outside venders participate as well, but the Ninth Avenue merchants and restaurants and the community organizations of Hell’s Kitchen are out in all their neighborhood glory.

To find me I will be waiting in front of the Starbucks. I will stay there for about 10 to 15 minutes. If we grow bored of the festival we will move to a nearby park, or walk around exploring the area. In the event of rain we will find an indoor activity like movie or a museum or find a place to grab brunch.

I recommend wearing comfortable shoes, bring a bottle and of water. And if you don't like large crowds, this might not be the meet-up for you.

For more information:

http://www.ninthavenuefoodfestival.com/
results.name: 9th Avenue International Food Festival +Explore the Highline

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
